channel.title: How would you defend a game from cheating?
channel.description:
i am days away from starting production on a game ive been designing. over 50 pages of design along with countless databases and formulas.
My game is a webpage based game, similair to neopets, just not gay, and more like a runescape style version.
I have my own ideas of how to combat against cheating bastards like you.... and me.... but how would you stop macroers from cheating in an online webpage based game.
One suggestion that has been given to me is having a predetermind amount of actions. so the player can mine 15 trees or fish 15 fish before he needs to 'rest' and enter a security password. This number of actions can be increased by training a skill specialy designed for actions.
While i hate this idea with every fiber in my body, its the best suggestion ive got so far.

item.title: How would you defend a game from cheating?
item.dc:creator: @Squigglyo Squigglyo
item.description:
@Squigglyo wrote:

well the way ive been thinking is

keep everything secret. every button, every variable, every form, is server side, and anything that is shown to the user, has a random name to it.

Also, every link just refreshes the page with different content, so noone can just type in www.thegame.com/trainfishing
since the only site would be www.thegame.com, just with a different script every time

item.description:

Making your own game client is retarded, then people like me will reverse it and export the functions from it
then be all like

Just trust nothing from the user, keep as many things server side as possible, then you’ll only have bots to deal with.

item.dc:creator: @runescape3dude runescape3dude
item.description:
@runescape3dude wrote:

Make your own game client… (like a trimmed down web browser that only has the functions required by your game.)

Then, make your server stop people from advancing in a skill for 30-45mins if they continuously repeat the same thing for 30-45 mins.

item.title: How would you defend a game from cheating?
item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:35, topic:257906”]CAPTCHA’s are not bulletproof either:

Some captchas have been solved with more than 90% accuracy by scientists specializing in computer vision research at the University of California, Berkeley, and elsewhere. Hobbyists also regularly write code to solve captchas on commercial sites with a high degree of accuracy.

Also cool things like this have been done:

Spammers are now using a new technique to circumvent the ‘captchas,’ the distorted text in graphics, that users must input to receive the free email account. The spammers have cracked the system by displaying the ‘captchas’ on free porn sites in real time. Since there are always a large number of people signing up for free porn, they do the work of decrypting the ‘captchas’ which is then replayed back into the spammers program to create a new email account. Who thought that porn could be a hacking technique!

So don’t rely on just one thing.[/quote]
Just hope that no scientist tries to cheat on your game or people with porno programs.
If you work a little on your CAPCHA it will block most of the cheaters.

item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Mopman:

I actually think its better to think abotu cheating from the ground up. Otherwise you end up basing your game around it entirely, and then fighting a losing battle when your players wont play your game legit.

You want to have a good base, checking everything on the server that you get from the client so items can’t be duplicated and such. But I don’t think you want to focus on blocking SCAR and such in the beginning.
